com.artisan.incodeapi
Class ArtisanExperimentManager

java.lang.Object
  com.artisan.incodeapi.ArtisanExperimentManager

public class ArtisanExperimentManager
extends java.lang.Object

Manages all in-code experiments designed for use with Artisan.

This includes:

  • Create in-code experiments
  • Adding variants to in-code experiments
  • Wrapping the code blocks to be executed for each variant
  • Setting additional analytics events to be tracked for in-code experiments
  • Setting the conversion target for an in-code experiment
  • ArtisanExperimentManager is a singleton that is automatically initialized when your app starts. Use ArtisanExperimentManager to manage all of your in-code experiments from inception to completion.

    All in-code experiments created using ArtisanExperimentManager can be registered with Artisan Tools. The registration process will automatically detect all created experiments along with their variants, and will automatically create a corresponding experiment on the Artisan Tools App page for this app. This experiment can then be modified, published, and observed like any other Artisan experiment. To test out your experiments before publishing your app, you should use the startExperiment(String, String) API call to programatically start your experiments in your test environment.

    Best Practices

  • For in-code experiments employing this class, you should test them out prior to shipping to the app store using startExperiment(String, String). This way you can preview their behavior and appearance.
  • Don't forget to remove the call to startExperiment(String, String) before you ship.

    public static ArtisanExperimentManager getInstance()

    registerExperiment

    public static void registerExperiment(java.lang.String experimentName)

    Create a new in-code experiment with Artisan.

    Use this method to declare the existence of an experiment you want to run with Artisan.
    This method should be called in the registerInCodeExperiments method of your CustomArtisanService.

     @Override
 public void registerInCodeExperiments() {
        ArtisanExperimentManager.registerExperiment("Cart Process");
  ...
 }

    Parameters:
    experimentName - The name of the experiment to register. This needs to be unique within your app, and should not contain periods or dollar signs.

    registerExperimentWithDescription

    public static void registerExperimentWithDescription(java.lang.String experimentName,
                                                     java.lang.String description)

    Register the new experiment with description

    Use this method to declare the existence of an experiment you want to run with Artisan.
    This method should be called in the registerInCodeExperiments method of your CustomArtisanService.

     @Override
 public void registerInCodeExperiments() {
        ArtisanExperimentManager.registerExperiment("Cart Process", "Skip or don't skip the product detail page");
  ...
 }

    Parameters:
    experimentName - The name of the experiment to register. This needs to be unique within your app, and should not contain periods or dollar signs.
    description - The description for this experiment. This will appear automatically when the experiment is registered with Artisan Tools.

    addVariantForExperiment

    public static void addVariantForExperiment(java.lang.String variantName,
                                           java.lang.String experimentName,
                                           boolean isDefault)
    Add a variant to an in-code experiment with Artisan and mark it as the default.

    Variants should be added immediately after the experiment is registered via registerExperiment(String) in your CustomArtisanService.
    Added variants will automatically be detected when the experiment is registered with Artisan Tools.
    Warning: Only one variant should be marked as the default. If more then one experiment is marked as the default, the last variant marke as default will be the default. 

     @Override
 public void registerInCodeExperiments() {
        ArtisanExperimentManager.registerExperiment("Cart Process");
        ArtisanExperimentManager.addVariantForExperiment("Don't Skip Product Details", "Cart Process", true);
  ...
 }

    Parameters:
    variantName - The name of the variant to add. This needs to be unique for the experiment.
    experimentName - The name of the experiment to which this variant should be added. This needs to be the name a variant previously created via registerExperiment(String)
    isDefault - Sets whether this variant is the default. The default variant will be used in instances where the experiment is not active (i.e. completed or not yet published)

    addVariantForExperiment

    public static void addVariantForExperiment(java.lang.String variantName,
                                           java.lang.String experimentName)

    Add a variant to an in-code experiment with Artisan.

    Variants should be added immediately after the experiment is registered via registerExperiment(String) in your CustomArtisanService.
    Added variants will automatically be detected when the experiment is registered with Artisan Tools.
    Warning: One variant should be marked as the default with addVariantForExperiment(String, String, boolean). If no variants are marked as the default, the first variant added to the experiment will automatically be the default. Use addVariantForExperiment(String, String, boolean) to explicitly mark a variant as the default. 

     @Override
 public void registerInCodeExperiments() {
        ArtisanExperimentManager.registerExperiment("Cart Process");
        ArtisanExperimentManager.addVariantForExperiment("Don't Skip Product Details", "Cart Process");
        ArtisanExperimentManager.addVariantForExperiment("Skip Product Details", "Cart Process");
 }

    Parameters:
    variantName - The name of the variant to add. This needs to be unique for the experiment.
    experimentName - The name of the experiment to which this variant should be added. This needs to be the name a variant previously created via registerExperiment(String)

    isCurrentVariantForExperiment

    public static boolean isCurrentVariantForExperiment(java.lang.String variantName,
                                                    java.lang.String experimentName)

    Check to see which variant is currently active.

    Use this method to wrap blocks of code that you want to execute for this variant of the specified experiment. For example, if you want to set the text of a TextView to 'Buy Now!' for variant 'A' of experiment 'Buy Button Test', your code would appear as follows: 

     if (ArtisanExperimentManager.isCurrentVariantForExperiment("button says add to cart", "Buy Button Test")) {
        textView.setText("Add to Cart");
 } else if (ArtisanExperimentManager.isCurrentVariantForExperiment("button says buy now", "Buy Button Test")) {
        textView.setText("Buy Now!");
 }

    Any experiment code can be wrapped in this manner, and these conditional blocks can be used in more than one location throughout your app.

    As for placement of this code you might find that the onResume method of your activity is a good place so that the appropriate changes will be made each time the user enters the activity.

    Parameters:
    variantName - Name of the variant. This must be the name of a variant already added to this experiment, otherwise false will automatically be returned.
    experimentName - Name of the experiment to which this variant belongs. This must be the name of an experiment already added to this app, otherwise false will automatically be returned.

    setTargetReachedForExperiment

    public static void setTargetReachedForExperiment(java.lang.String experimentName)

    Set the conversion target for the specified experiment. 

     ArtisanExperimentManager.setTargetReachedForExperiment("Add To Cart Button Test");

    Use this method to specify what the conversion target should be for an in-code experiment. The conversion target is the end of your funnel - the action that this variant is trying to maximize.

    The target set in code can be overridden by Artisan Tools as necessary. In these cases, the target will be tracked as an ordinary analytics event.

    Warning: If no target is specified for an experiment, your conversion rate for this test will default to zero percent. If more than one target is specified for an experiment, the target will be the first conversion event reported by a user device.

    Warning: Take care when calling this method to make sure that it only gets triggered when the user performs the intended action. For example, if it is possible for the user to navigate away from the target and back again, make sure this doesn't count as two conversions unless that is your intention.

    Parameters:
    experimentName - Name of the experiment for which the target is being set. Leading and trailing whitespace of experimentName will be trimmed. Must be a valid experiment.

    setTargetReachedForExperiment

    public static void setTargetReachedForExperiment(java.lang.String experimentName,
                                                 java.lang.String description)

    Set the conversion target for the specified experiment, with an attached description. 

     ArtisanExperimentManager.setTargetReachedForExperiment("Add To Cart Button Test", "Item added to cart");

    Use this method to specify what the conversion target should be for an in-code experiment. The conversion target is the end of your funnel - the action that this variant is trying to maximize.

    Warning: If no target is specified for an experiment, your conversion rate for this test will default to zero percent. If more than one target is specified for an experiment, the target will be the first conversion event reported by a user device.

    Parameters:
    experimentName - Name of the experiment for which the target is being set. Leading and trailing whitespace of experimentName will be trimmed. Must be a valid experiment.
    description - Description of the target, which will be displayed to the user on the Artisan Tools website.

    setExperimentViewedForExperiment

    public static void setExperimentViewedForExperiment(java.lang.String experimentName)

    Indicate that the experiment has been viewed. 

     ArtisanExperimentManager.setExperimentViewedForExperiment("Add To Cart Button Test");

    Use this method to specify that your experiment has been viewed by the user. When this code is triggered, an experiment view officially begins. This experiment view counts as a conversion if setTargetReachedForExperiment(String) is called for this experiment before (a) setExperimentViewedForExperiment(String) gets called again for this experiment or (b) the app is backgrounded.

    It is essential to call this method at least once for each experiment that you build to ensure that you will get an accurate conversion rate.

    We recommend that you place this in onResume for your activity so that it will be called each time the user sees the activity.

    Warning: Placement of this event is critical to creating useful and accurate analytics. Make sure this code fires ONLY when you deem that the user has encountered your experiment. Consider cases where this method is fired, then the target for this experiment is reached, which transitions back to the same code that originally triggered this method. The conversion rate would now be 50%, rather than 100%, since this method was called twice.

    Parameters:
    experimentName - Name of the experiment that has been viewed. Leading and trailing whitespace will be trimmed. Must be a valid experiment.

    startExperiment

    public static void startExperiment(java.lang.String experimentName,
                                   java.lang.String variantName)

    Start an in-code Artisan experiment manually.

    Use this method to manually start an experiment built using the Artisan in-code API. The app will behave as if the experiment has been published and the user has received the variant specified.

    This method should be called in the registerPowerhooks method of your CustomArtisanService after you have registered the experiment.

    Note: This method is intended for local test and QA use only, and should *not* be used within production code.

    Parameters:
    variantName - Name of the variant to apply for this experiment. This should be one of the variants added to the experiment. If the name is invalid, the experiment will apply the default variant.
    experimentName - Name of the experiment being started.

    startExperiment

    public static void startExperiment(java.lang.String experimentName,
                                   java.lang.String variantName,
                                   java.util.Date startDate,
                                   java.util.Date endDate,
                                   java.lang.String variationId)

    Start an in-code Artisan experiment manually.

    Use this method to manually start an experiment built using the Artisan in-code API. The app will behave as if the experiment has been published and the user has received the variant specified.

    This method should be called in the registerPowerhooks method of your CustomArtisanService after you have registered the experiment.

    Note: This method is intended for local test and QA use only, and should *not* be used within production code.

    Parameters:
    variantName - Name of the variant to apply for this experiment. This should be one of the variants added to the experiment. If the name is invalid, the experiment will apply the default variant.
    experimentName - Name of the experiment being started.
    startDate - the date at which this experiment should start running. May be null. If null then the experiment will run forever.
    endDate - the date at which this experiment should no longer run. May be null. If null then the experiment will run forever.
    variationId - the unique id for the active experiment from Artisan Tools. May be null.

    isRunning

    public static boolean isRunning(java.util.Date now,
                                java.util.Date start,
                                java.util.Date end)

    getNowUTC

    public static java.util.Date getNowUTC()

    getAllExperiments

    public static java.util.HashMap<java.lang.String,Experiment> getAllExperiments()
    Retrieve all registered in-code experiments.

    Returns:
    HashMap of the current experiments, where the keys are the String names of the experiments, and the values are Experiment objects.

    clearAll

    public static void clearAll()
    Remove all registered experiments

    Note: This method is intended for local test and QA use only, and should *not* be used within production code.

    stopAllExperiments

    public static void stopAllExperiments()
    Stops all experiments. The default variants will be current again.

    Note: This method is intended for local test and QA use only, and should *not* be used within production code.
